Value-Added Services
18.13.13 Insurance

18.13.13 Insurance
Each Party shall maintain adequate insurance or shall self-insure at an appropriate level with
respect to the business activities carried out by such Party in the ordinary course. Each Party
shall furnish certificates of insurance to the other Party upon reasonable request.

18.13.14 Area of Use
The Customer shall access, use, and accept provision of the Value-Added Services and
Deliverables solely in the Territory.

18.13.15 Order of Precedence
With respect to those Value-Added Services in which a Customer elects to participate on or
after the initial publication date of these Value-Added Services Rules, in the event of an express
conflict between and among provisions of these Value-Added Services Rules, the
Documentation and other Mastercard Rules, the following order of precedence shall apply, in
descending order: (i) Documentation published in whole or in part on or after the initial
publication of these Value-Added Services Rules; (ii) these Value-Added Services Rules; (iii) the
Mastercard Rules; and (iv) existing Documentation published prior to the initial publication of
these Value-Added Services Rules.

18.13.16 Survival
The expiration or termination, for any reason, of these Value-Added Services Rules will not
affect (i) the rights of either Party against the other that have accrued on or prior to the
termination; or (ii) any provision that, by its nature, survives the termination of these ValueAdded Services Rules, including Rule 18.5 (“Confidentiality”), Rule 18.6 (“Privacy and Data
Protection”), the ownership provisions within Rule 18.7, Rule 18.11 (“Indemnification”), Rule
18.12 (“Limitation of Liability”), and Rule 18.13 (“Miscellaneous”), which shall survive any
termination or expiration of the Enrollment Form or applicable Documentation.

18.13.17 Europe Variances and Additions
These Europe Variances and Additions, including the defined terms set forth herein, are part of
the Value-Added Services Rules, and are applicable only to Customers subject to the Digital
Operational Resilience Regulation in the European Union to the extent that the Value-Added
Services are deemed by Mastercard and the Customer to be classified as ICT services under the
Digital Operational Resilience Regulation.
The provisions in this section related to Critical or Important Functions apply only when the
Documentation identifies that a Value-Added Service supports Critical or Important Functions.
As used in this section, the following terms have the meanings as described below.
"Critical or Important Functions" have the meaning given to it by the Digital Operational
Resilience Regulation.

© 1969–2025 Mastercard. Proprietary. All rights reserved.

Mastercard Rules • 3 June 2025

412

Value-Added Services
18.13.17.1 Identification

"Critical Supplier" means the Mastercard Supplier that effectively underpins the Value-Added
Service supporting the Critical or Important Function or material part thereof, including the
Mastercard Supplier providing ICT services whose disruption would impair the security or the
continuity of the service provision.
"Digital Operational Resilience Regulation" means the Regulation (EU) 2022/2554 of the
European Parliament and of the Council of 14 December 2022 on digital operational resilience
for the financial sector (as amended and replaced from time to time).
"ICT" means information and communication technology.
18.13.17.1 Identification
If requested by a Customer, Mastercard will reasonably provide the Customer with, or otherwise
indicate the source of, information justifiably required by the Customer under the Digital
Operational Resilience Regulation for the proper identification of Mastercard or its Critical
Suppliers.
18.13.17.2 Security Standards
During the delivery of Value-Added Services, Mastercard will maintain certain security
standards as described in the Documentation and these Value-Added Services Rules, designed
to ensure that Customer Materials are secure and available to the Customer. Mastercard will
ensure that any ICT systems on which it holds any Customer Materials are secure systems that
comply with high data security standards.
18.13.17.3 Data Location
Mastercard will identify and notify the Customer of any locations (countries or regions) in which
Mastercard or any of the Mastercard Suppliers processes Customer Materials (personal or
nonpersonal data) or from which Mastercard or Critical Supplier provides Value-Added Services.
Neither Mastercard nor Mastercard Suppliers may change the country or region from which
Value-Added Services are provided or where Customer Materials are stored or processed
without notifying the Customer at least thirty (30) days in advance. If the Customer objects to
any such proposed change of country or region due to reasonable concerns with compliance
with applicable law, including cybersecurity concerns, and if Mastercard or Mastercard Suppliers
nonetheless choose to implement the proposed change and no other arrangement is agreed
with the Customer within thirty (30) days from the Customer's notification of their objection:
(i) the Customer will be entitled to terminate its use of the Value-Added Services affected by
the change with effect from the announced date of Mastercard's implementation of the
change; and (ii) any minimum notice period which would otherwise apply to such termination
will not apply.
18.13.17.4 Return of Customer Materials
If a Customer's access to the Value-Added Services ends in any way, which includes but is not
limited to any case of termination, or in the event of the insolvency, resolution, or

© 1969–2025 Mastercard. Proprietary. All rights reserved.

Mastercard Rules • 3 June 2025

413

Value-Added Services
18.13.17.5 Incident Handling Procedures

discontinuation of the business of Mastercard, notwithstanding any other obligations of
Mastercard or the Customer under the Value-Added Services Rules, Mastercard will at the
Customer's written request addressed within thirty (30) days of the end of the Value-Added
Services, to the extent permitted by the applicable laws, return to the Customer or delete all
and any Customer Materials (including personal and nonpersonal data) processed by
Mastercard or Mastercard Suppliers in order to perform the Value-Added Services. Upon receipt
of such request, Mastercard will return the Customer Materials by regular means as then
offered by Mastercard and the Customer will pay the then current rates for Mastercard's
assistance.
18.13.17.5 Incident Handling Procedures
Unless specific incident handling procedures were agreed in the Documentation, in the event of
an ICT-related Incident (as defined in Digital Operational Resilience Regulation) affecting ValueAdded Services, without additional fees, Mastercard will provide the Customer with any
reasonably requested information in Mastercard's possession on the ICT-related Incident that
the Customer needs to secure the Customer's cybersecurity and continuity of the Customer's
functions at risk due to the ICT-related Incident. Where the Value-Added Services support
Critical or Important Functions, Mastercard will: (i) notify the Customer via centralized
subscription-based alerting of any such ICT-related Incident that could negatively impact the
continuity or security of the Value-Added Services provided to the Customer; and (ii) inform the
Customer of how the ICT-related Incident was handled by Mastercard.
Any further assistance will be provided to the Customer at the Customer's request and at the
then current rates offered by Mastercard. Such assistance will be limited to the services
described in Documentation or otherwise notified to the Customer.
18.13.17.6 Cooperation with Authorities
To the extent required by applicable law, Mastercard will cooperate with all competent
authorities and resolution authorities of the Customer, including persons appointed by them.
Such requested cooperation cannot lead to or result in a breach of any legal obligations of
Mastercard, in particular confidentiality obligations towards its other Customers or obligations
towards other competent authorities, or disturb the Value-Added Services provided to such
other Customers.
The Customer will bear the costs arising out of any extraordinary cooperation efforts, including,
but not limited to those resulting from extensive data retrieval and deployment of specialized
personnel.
18.13.17.7 Special Termination Provisions
Notwithstanding any other termination provisions in the Value-Added Services Rules, the
Customer will be entitled to terminate its use of the Value-Added Services in any of the
following circumstances: (i) a significant breach by Mastercard of applicable laws; (ii) material
changes to the Value-Added Services or the Value-Added Services Rules that adversely affect
the Customer's ability to meet its regulatory obligations under applicable laws, in such case,
Mastercard will first discuss with the Customer how to accommodate the Customer's

© 1969–2025 Mastercard. Proprietary. All rights reserved.

Mastercard Rules • 3 June 2025

414

Value-Added Services
18.13.17.8 ICT Testing

regulatory obligations and the Customer will have a right to terminate its use of the ValueAdded Services by giving sixty (60) days' prior written notice to Mastercard if Mastercard and
the Customer are not able to satisfy those regulatory obligations; (iii) Mastercard's evidenced
major weaknesses pertaining to its overall ICT risk management, and in particular in the way
Mastercard ensures the availability, authenticity, integrity and confidentiality of data, whether
personal data, otherwise sensitive data or non-personal data, where this was not addressed in
accordance with good market standards within thirty (30) days of being notified by the
Customer in writing; and (iv) where the competent authority states that it can no longer
effectively supervise the Customer as a result of the conditions of, or circumstances related to,
the Value-Added Services; in such case, Mastercard will first discuss with the Customer how to
accommodate to the competent authority's requirements and the Customer will have a right to
terminate its use of the Value-Added Services by giving sixty (60) days' prior written notice to
Mastercard if Mastercard and the Customer are not able to satisfy those requirements.
18.13.17.8 ICT Testing
Where the Value-Added Services support Critical or Important Functions, Mastercard and its
Critical Suppliers will organize audits and ICT testing, including threat-led penetration testing,
on request from the Customer or competent authorities, as the case may be, on the following
conditions: (i) the Customer will provide Mastercard with a nine (9) months' notice of its
intention to perform an ICT testing; (ii) Mastercard will combine requests to perform ICT testing
(including threat-led penetration testing) into a single testing event ("ICT pooled testing"); (iii)
the Customer and Mastercard will jointly define the scope of the ICT pooled testing in advance
of its commencement; (iv) Mastercard and its Critical Suppliers will participate in the audits and
ICT pooled testing to the extent required under applicable laws; (v) the abovementioned will be
limited in scope and frequency as described in the Documentation; (vi) the Customer will pay
Mastercard for any costs associated with and a for the abovementioned services at the then
current rates as provided for in the Documentation or otherwise notified to the Customer; (vii)
Mastercard will not bear the cost of organizing and conducting the audits and ICT pooled
testing; (viii) the Customer will be liable for any damages caused by the Customer's gross
negligence, willful misconduct or material breach of any of its obligations hereunder, arising
during ICT testing; and (ix) Mastercard will be exempt from liability for any failure or delay to
perform the Value-Added Services to the extent such failure or delay is attributable to the
abovementioned ICT testing.
18.13.17.9 Audit and Access Right
Where the Value-Added Services support Critical or Important Functions, the Customer and its
competent authority, and any other auditor appointed by the Customer or competent authority,
will be granted, once in every twelve (12) month's period, or upon material changes to the
Value-Added Services: (i) access to Mastercard's relevant operational business premises,
including to data and similar operation centers, relevant devices, systems, networks, information
and data other than Customer Materials used for providing the Value-Added Services; and (ii)
rights of inspection and auditing related to the applicable Value-Added Services pursuant to
these Value-Added Services Rules, to enable them to audit the provision of the Value-Added
Services pursuant to the Enrollment Form, the Documentation and these Value-Added Services

© 1969–2025 Mastercard. Proprietary. All rights reserved.

Mastercard Rules • 3 June 2025

415

Value-Added Services
18.13.17.9 Audit and Access Right

Rules, and to ensure compliance with applicable laws. The abovementioned rights are granted
provided that the Customer and its competent authority, and any other auditor appointed by
the Customer or competent authority, proves that the scope of access, audit or inspection
required from Mastercard is justified under applicable law and not achievable by alternative
means. The exercise of the abovementioned rights is subject to acceptance of and adherence to
requirements set out by Mastercard in respect of security of its facilities and proprietary
information.
The Customer and the appointed auditor will execute a written confidentiality agreement
acceptable to Mastercard or otherwise will be bound by a statutory or legal confidentiality
obligation before executing the audit and access rights granted by this Section.
Notwithstanding the above, any information provided by Mastercard or otherwise accessed by
the Customer during the audit procedures will be deemed to be Mastercard's Confidential
Information.
Nothing in these Value-Added Services Rules entitles any competent authority, auditor or the
Customer to have access to information about any other Mastercard Customer or to any parts
of the Mastercard business that are not engaged in the provision of the Value-Added Services to
the Customer.
Unless a shorter period is imposed by applicable law or by the competent authority, the
Customer is obliged to provide Mastercard with at least sixty (60) days' written notice prior to
conducting an on-site audit or inspection. The audit or inspection has to be conducted during
Mastercard regular business hours, cannot interfere with regular business activities and cannot
last longer than three (3) business days in the location where the audit or inspection takes place.
Unless required by applicable law, Mastercard will not be obliged to disclose information in
relation to any audit where to do so would put Mastercard in breach of any confidentiality
obligations it owes to third parties, or would infringe a third party's intellectual property rights
or otherwise be unlawful.
Mastercard and its Critical Suppliers will fully cooperate with the Customer and its competent
authorities in any regulatory queries, proceedings and other mandatory regulatory activities,
subject to binding legal obligations of Mastercard, either towards third parties and/or relevant
authorities, and subject to payment by the Customer of remuneration for such cooperation at
the then current rates at Mastercard or its Critical Supplier.
If an audit reveals that Mastercard or its Critical Supplier are out of compliance with applicable
laws or these Value-Added Services Rules, including the Enrollment Form and Documentation,
the Customer will inform Mastercard of any such non-compliance without undue delay, and
Mastercard will take, or will cause that its Critical Supplier takes, the action reasonably and
justifiably needed to correct the identified non-compliances at its own expense.
For the avoidance of doubt, the meaning and scope of an audit and access right described in
this Section is to be interpreted in accordance with the provisions of Digital Operational
Resilience Regulation, the Regulatory Technical Standards issued under the Digital Operational
Resilience Regulation, and any applicable regulatory guidelines, as amended or replaced from
time to time.

© 1969–2025 Mastercard. Proprietary. All rights reserved.

Mastercard Rules • 3 June 2025

416

Value-Added Services
18.13.17.10 Rights Upon Termination or Expiration

18.13.17.10 Rights Upon Termination or Expiration
Where the Value-Added Services support Critical or Important Functions, and unless otherwise
agreed in the Documentation or the Enrollment Form, upon a written request by the Customer,
Mastercard will grant the Customer a limited right to use the Value-Added Services for a
maximum period of thirty (30) days from the date of termination or expiration of the
Enrollment Form, at the standard cost of the Value-Added Services, solely to retrieve the
Customer Materials, provided that: (i) the Customer did not retrieve Customer Materials before
the date of termination or expiration of the Value-Added Services; and (ii) following the
expiration of that period, Mastercard will have the right to delete the Customer Materials, or to
retain them, whichever is required by the applicable laws.
Where the Value-Added Services support Critical or Important Functions, Mastercard and its
Critical Suppliers will reasonably cooperate to support the Customer in the orderly transfer of
the outsourced functions in the event of the termination of the Value-Added Services, subject to
the payment by the Customer of remuneration at then current rates at Mastercard. Any
support other than making the Customer Materials available to the Customer and providing
basic information on the outsourced function will be separately agreed with the Customer as a
separate service and subject to separate fee.
18.13.17.11 Sub-contracting
Mastercard is authorized to subcontract the Value-Added Services, including those supporting
Critical or Important Functions of the Customer, or parts thereof.
Where the Value-Added Services which support Critical or Important Functions or material
parts thereof are subcontracted to Critical Suppliers, Mastercard will: (i) be responsible for the
provision of the services by Critical Suppliers (ii) monitor that ICT services provided by Critical
Suppliers meet Mastercard's contractual obligations before the Customer; (iii) monitor and
report to the Customer regarding Critical Suppliers as set out in the Value-Added Services Rules
and the Documentation; (iv) assess risks associated with the location of Critical Suppliers and
their parent company and the location from which the ICT service is provided; (v) where
relevant, specify the location of data processed or stored by Critical Suppliers in the
Documentation; (vi) identify the chain of Critical Suppliers and keep the identification
information up to date; (vii) ensure the continuity of the Value-Added Services which support
Critical or Important Functions throughout the subcontracting chain in case of failure by the
Critical Suppliers to meet their contractual obligations; (viii) require the Critical Suppliers to
grant the Customer and competent and resolution authorities sufficient rights of access,
inspection and audit as required under the Digital Operational Resilience Regulation and granted
to the Customer and competent and resolution authorities by Mastercard; (ix) allow the
Customer to obtain from Mastercard reasonably and justifiably requested information on
contractual documentation between Mastercard and Critical Suppliers, and on relevant
performance indicators; (x) notify the Customer, with a notice period of at least thirty (30)
days, of material changes to arrangements with Critical Suppliers.
Mastercard will specify in its agreements with Critical Suppliers of the Value-Added Services
supporting Critical or Important Functions or material parts thereof: (i) the Critical Supplier's
monitoring and reporting obligations towards Mastercard and, where agreed with the

© 1969–2025 Mastercard. Proprietary. All rights reserved.

Mastercard Rules • 3 June 2025

417

Value-Added Services
18.13.17.11 Sub-contracting

Customer, towards the Customer; (ii) the Critical Supplier's obligations to implement and test
business contingency plans and related service levels; (iii) the ICT security standards and any
additional security requirements, where relevant, that must be met by the Critical Suppliers in
order to provide an appropriate level of security for the provision of services by the Customer in
line with its regulatory framework.
Customer will be further entitled to terminate its use of the Value-Added Services supporting
Critical or Important Functions in case Mastercard implements material changes to the
arrangements with related Critical Suppliers despite the objection by the Customer submitted
to Mastercard within the notice period specified in point (x) above or before the end of that
notice period, or if Mastercard subcontracts the Value-Added Services supporting Critical or
Important Functions that were not explicitly permitted to be subcontracted.
